item.title: Public office isn’t ‘mom-friendly.’ Women lawmakers are changing that.
item.description: Family duties are one reason mothers don’t run for office. Now some are advocating for on-site day care, higher wages, and child care funding.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Babcock

item.title: In US capital, rats thrive where civic trust is low. Here’s how to fix that.
item.description: From the Rose Garden to the Capitol, in the rat battle in the nation’s capital, victory can be measured in civic cooperation, not total destruction.
item.dc:creator: Christa Case Bryant
Sophie Hills

item.title: Math, English, and bright smiles. Traveling dental care in schools fills a gap.
item.description: Nearly half of all U.S. children don’t receive regular dental care, according to a federal report. School-based traveling dental clinics are trying to change that, along with other community health programs and nonprofits.
item.dc:creator: Michael Casey

item.title: The US is seeing a stadium construction boom. Who’s paying for it?
item.description: A proposed sales tax hike to fund stadium projects in Kansas City failed this week at the ballot box. When pro sports teams don’t get the public funds they seek, some double down on a pitch to voters or go to legislators. Others threaten to move.
item.dc:creator: David A. Lieb

item.title: No prescription? No problem. Birth control pills hit shelves.
item.description: Birth control pills are now on sale in the U.S. without a prescription. As states wrestle with abortion, some say this option for women is crucial.
item.dc:creator: Ali Martin

item.title: Trump defied political norms. Now he tests the stock market.
item.description: Some call Trump Media & Technology Group a “meme stock.” But in financial markets, confidence tends to hinge on fundamentals of finance, not the risky ground of emotion or personal trust.
item.dc:creator: Laurent Belsie

item.title: Georgia residents could gain new power to strike fellow voters from the rolls
item.description: Georgia Republicans are seeking further restrictions on who can cast a ballot. Lawmakers passed a bill that allows “vigilante” challenges to large numbers of voter registrations, a move opponents say could see legitimate voters struck from the rolls.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Amy

item.title: Kept on the sidelines, Black assistant basketball coaches want a shot to lead
item.description: Black head coaches are still a rarity in college basketball, despite a growing number of Black coaches rising to the level of assistant coach. Long seen as just recruiters, Black coaches are hoping to take up top posts that don’t change hands often.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Beard

item.title: These local newspapers were struggling. Then student journalists took charge.
item.description: As news deserts grow across the U.S., college newspapers could offer a solution. The Daily Iowan, a student paper for the University of Iowa, bought two struggling local papers which student journalists will help run, in a first-of-its-kind deal.
item.dc:creator: Heather Hollingsworth

item.title: Why drivers may soon pay $15 to use New York’s busiest streets
item.description: New York is the first U.S. city to approve a congestion charge for driving in its busiest districts. Revenues are earmarked for public transit investments.
item.dc:creator: Hillary Chura

item.title: NATO has united the West for 75 years. Here’s why it still matters.
item.description: Born out of the ashes of World War II, NATO and its values have framed Western diplomacy for decades. Is the alliance still relevant?
item.dc:creator: Howard LaFranchi
Anna Mulrine Grobe

item.title: A solar eclipse is coming April 8. Here’s what you need to know.
item.description: The total solar eclipse on April 8 will be visible to millions of Americans. Here’s a guide to how and where to watch it and what to expect.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Babcock

item.title: The case for getting and staying married, by author Brad Wilcox
item.description: Sociologist Brad Wilcox discusses his research on declining U.S. marriage rates in a Q&A about his new book, “Get Married.”
item.dc:creator: Simon Montlake

item.title: Chaplains serve in hospitals and colleges. Should they be in public schools?
item.description: Conservatives in more than a dozen states are hoping to reform public school cultures by installing chaplains. The initiatives are drawing concern from some chaplains and interfaith organizations.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fingerhut

item.title: Transportation spending surges to historic levels. Will US get historic results?
item.description: The U.S. has never spent so much on transportation, water systems, and other networks. Whether it will get once-in-a-generation results is unclear.
item.dc:creator: Laurent Belsie

item.title: Birthrates are tumbling worldwide, forcing hard choices on societies
item.description: After a century in which the global population grew almost fourfold, a turning point awaits. In the next century, the world's population is expected to peak, leading to questions about how best to sustain thriving societies.
item.dc:creator: Simon Montlake

item.title: Sam Bankman-Fried’s 25-year sentence shows crypto schemers can't hide
item.description: Sam Bankman-Fried started the second most popular digital currency exchange – until it collapsed three years after it began. Now, he’s been sentenced to 25 years in prison for misusing billions of customer dollars.
item.dc:creator: Luc Cohen and Jody Godoy

item.title: Tyre Nichols’ death sparked policing reforms. Why state legislators reversed them.
item.description: After the fatal January 2023 beating of Tyre Nichols, the city of Memphis outlawed pretextual traffic stops and implemented other reforms. But Republicans in the state legislature pushed to overturn them over the Nichols family’s objections.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Mattise

item.title: Key Bridge is gone. It leaves a hole in Baltimore’s blue-collar soul.
item.description: Before it collapsed, Baltimore’s Key Bridge was a city icon. You could see it from everywhere. It had a personality – blue-collar, like the city.
item.dc:creator: Peter Grier

item.title: ‘We’re ready to help.’ East Coast ports welcome cargo bound for Baltimore.
item.description: The collapsed Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore raised concerns about another U.S. supply chain crisis. But East Coast ports have invested billions of dollars over the past decade to expand capacity and stand ready to receive cargo.
item.dc:creator: David Lawder
